Mark Farrell

Strongly Regular Grassman Graphs

Jan 5, 2017

In this post, my goal is to determine the parameters of the Grassman graphs that are strongly regular. To this end, my primary goal is to verify that:

  • For all natural numbers and prime powers , the Grassman graph is an .

Suppose that we are given an arbitrary natural number and prime power . Let denote the set of all subspaces of dimension of a vector space of dimension over the finite field of order . Consider the simple graph formed with the set as vertices and the set as edges. Then:

  1. Select an arbitrary . Then there are = = ways to select a vector in that is not also a vector in , and for each there are other vectors in that are non-zero scalar multiples of . This means that there are ways to select a one-dimensional subspace of and then select another one-dimensional subspace of where in order to construct a two-dimensional subspace of such that . Hence is adjacent to vertices in , which is independent of itself; therefore we ultimately have that is -regular.

  2. Select an arbitrary , and let . Additionally, let , where and denote the respective neighbourhoods of and on . Partition into disjoint subsets and . Now, there are ways to select a one-dimensional subspace of where in order to construct a two-dimensional subspace of such that ; this means here that , subtracting one to exclude from this count. There are then ways to select a one-dimensional subspace of of and then select a one-dimensional of in order to construct a two-dimensional subspace of V such that ; this means here that . Hence . Therefore every pair of adjacent vertices on share neighbours in common, since the choice of edge in this context is arbitrary.

  3. Select an arbitrary pair and of distinct non-adjacent vertices in . Then there ways to select a one-dimensional subspace of and then select a one-dimensional subspace of in order to construct a two-dimensional subspace of such that and ; this means here that and share neighbours in common. Therefore every pair of distinct non-adjacent vertices on share neighbours in common, since and in this context are arbitrary.

Hence is an ; the general result then follows, since and in this context are arbitrary.

Note that , the diameter of is , and is strongly regular if and only if its diameter is 2 for all natural numbers where and prime powers . The parameters of any strongly regular Grassman graph can then be deduced from this, together with the result that I have verified in this post.
